body:
As @mklement0 [mentions in his thought](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/14732#issuecomment-817366599) and my own feature request for "[Calculated Objects](https://github.com/iRon7/Join-Object/issues/20)" related to the propose [Add a Join-Object cmdlet to the standard PowerShell equipment `#14994`](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/14994), the suggested "**deferred pipeline *object***" doesn't differ much from an `[ScriptBlock]`. The difference is in how it is invoked. Meaning that rather than returning all the output items in once, I would like to retrieve just *a single **next*** item and literally ***stall***¹ the (deferred) pipeline. Also knowing that it might be confusing if a variable changes just on the fly when it has been access, it would probably make more sense to implement a distinct syntax (e.g. by using a `%` rather than a `$` for the concerned expression variable) at the invocation side.

<sub>**1.** as apposed to "**choke**", where the items are continued to be enumerated in memory</sub>

This:
```PowerShell
%Count
```
Causes currently an error:
> %Count: The term '%Count' is not recognized as a name of a cmdlet, function, script file, or executable program.
> Check the spelling of the name, or if a path was included, verify that the path is correct and try again.

Wishful thinking:
```PowerShell
$Count = { 1..3 } # Initialize the deferred pipeline object
%Count
1
%Count
2
%Count
3
%Count # Nothing (`AutomationNull`) returns
```

More specific:
```PowerShell
$a = { Get-Connect .\MyHughFile.txt } # or any other long stream
$b = { 1..1e9 } # In the idea, the range shouldn't affect the memory used for $b 
$c = { Import-Csv .\Large.csv }
%a | ForEach-Object { # Not sure about this but could simply be: `Get-Connect .\MyHughFile.txt |ForEach-Object ...`
    Write-Host '$a item:' $_ 
    Write-Host '$b item:' %b # Every time the %b is used, it processes the next item in the deferred $b expression
    Write-Host '$c item:' %c # Ditto for $c
}
```

@vexx32
>  It reminds me a lot of `-PipelineVariable`

I don't think it is the same as the `-PipelineVariable`. As the  `-PipelineVariable` assigns "*current*" items  (`$PSItem`) to different variables in the ***same*** pipeline and the proposal concerns ***separated*** pipelines (and assignments). Although, I do agree that the propose probably adds quite some complexity.

> it's not possible to really defer the creation of the whole array without completely re-architecting how the `..` operator  itself works.

I agree: it probably doesn't give any advantage for this specific statement (other than a possible syntactical advantage). Nevertheless, I wonder whether it could improve memory usage and performance¹ when I would load items from e.g. a file (`1..1e9 | Set-Content .\List.txt`). Unfortunately, I can't that this with your code example as the parentheses required for this '(Set-Content .\List.txt`).GetEnumerator()` would already load everything in memory...

<sub>**1.** in case not all lines are eventually loaded, given the example where the `ForEach` will only loop a `100` times</sub>

I like the idea too, but as suggested in https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/14732#issuecomment-817366599, perhaps it is sufficient to offer this object-at-a-time-in-lockstep processing via `ForEach-Object` rather than devising new syntax:

```powershell
# WISHFUL THINKING
{ 0..2 }, { 'a'..'c' } | ForEach-Object -InvokeScriptBlocks -Process { '{0}: {1}' -f $_[0], $_[1] }
0: a
1: b
2: c
```

That is, switch `-InvokeScriptBlocks` would interpret _script blocks_ passed as input as the input-data _generators_ to execute step by step, in tandem, via [`SteppablePipeline`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-US/dotnet/api/System.Management.Automation.SteppablePipeline)s (as also used for [proxy functions](https://stackoverflow.com/a/62861781/45375)), with the collected results from each step passed to the `-Process` script block.

_Update_: See [@SeeminglyScience's explanation below](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/15206#issuecomment-818920122) for why steppable pipelines aren't a good solution.

<details>
<summary>Obsolete solution attempt.</summary>

I tried to put together a quick proof-of-concept, but got stuck:

* I couldn't figure how to _capture_ the output from `.Process()` calls on steppable pipelines
* or how to detect when they're done producing output.

See my attempt below. @SeeminglyScience, any thoughts?

```powershell
function ForEach-SteppableObject {
  [CmdletBinding(PositionalBinding=$false)]
  param(
    [Parameter(Mandatory, Position=0)]
    [scriptblock] $Process
    ,
    [Parameter(Mandatory, ValueFromPipeline)]
    [scriptblock] $InputScriptBlock
  )

  begin {
    $allInputScriptBlocks = [System.Collections.Generic.List[scriptblock]]::new()
  }

  process {
    $allInputScriptBlocks.Add($InputScriptBlock)
  }

  end {

    [PowerShell[]] $psInstances = foreach ($sb in $allInputScriptBlocks) { [powershell]::Create().AddScript($sb) }
    
    [System.Management.Automation.SteppablePipeline[]] $steppablePipelines = $psInstances.GetSteppablePipeline()
  
    $steppablePipelines.Begin($false)

    do {
      # !! THIS IS THE PART THAT DOESN'T WORK.
      # !! The script blocks' output objects aren't being returned as part of the .Process()
      # !! call, and it's unclear to me how to get it to do that.
      [array] $outputs = $steppablePipelines.Process()

      # Pass the outputs from this step to the -Process script block.
      ForEach-Object -InputObject $outputs -Process $Process

    } while (($outputs -eq $null).Count -ne $outputs.Count) 
    # !! This currently results in an infinite loop, because each .Process()
    # !! call returns an empty array.
    # !! Without input being fed to the input script blocks, it's also not
    # !! clear to me how to reliably detect when a script block has stopped
    # !! producing.
  
    $steppablePipelines.End()

    $psInstances.Dispose()
  }

}

# Sample call:
# CAVEAT: Currently results in an infinite loop.
{ Write-Output (1..3) }, { Write-Output ('a'..'c') } | ForEach-SteppableObject { '{0}: {1}' -f $_[0], $_[1] } 
```
</details>
Just a thought: there might be a performance advantage (for larger pipelines) if the deferred input pipeline runs really in parallel.

Thanks for the commends and prototypes.

@SeeminglyScience,
Unfortuanetely, I can't get you C example to run as I get an error:

> ```
> Line |
>  132 |  Add-Type -TypeDefinition $Source
>      |  ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
>      | (59,49): error CS8652: The feature 'not pattern' is currently in Preview and *unsupported*. To use Preview features, use the 'preview' language version.                 bool expectingInput =
>      | _input is not null;                                                 ^
> ```

The error is quiet clear but I have you clue how to resolve this (and is I want this, maybe I should do some more playing around in a sandbox).

@mklement0,
I have had it some deeper thoughts and I agree that this shouldn't require a different syntax.
But I think that the `ForEach-Object` should have an additional parameter instead, something like `-SynchronouslyProcess <ScriptBlock[]>` knowing that the parallel pipelines supplied are actually not a part of the (main) pipeline but (initially) nothing more than static scriptblocks.

What I have for testing:
```PowerShell
$Command = { GCI }                                              # a Synchronic Process
$Sync = [hashtable]::Synchronized(@{
    Command = $Command
    WaitMain = [System.Threading.AutoResetEvent]::new($True)
    WaitJob = [System.Threading.AutoResetEvent]::new($False)
    Output = $Null
})

$Script = {
    param($Sync)
    Invoke-Command $Sync['Command'] |
    ForEach-Object { 
        $Sync['Output'] = $_                                    # Should be a data collector?
        $Null = $Sync['WaitJob'].Set()                          # For multiple parallel pipelines use a barrier?
        $Null = $Sync['WaitMain'].WaitOne(10000)
    }
    $Sync['Output'] = &{}
    $Null = $Sync['WaitJob'].Set()
}

$PowerShell = [PowerShell]::Create()
$Null = $PowerShell.AddScript($Script).AddArgument($Sync)
$Job = $PowerShell.BeginInvoke()
Sleep -Milliseconds 500                                         #7626 Prevent a "Stack Empty"
1..9 |ForEach-Object {                                          # Start the main pipeline
    $SyncItem = if ($Null -ne $PowerShell) {
        $Null = $Sync['WaitMain'].Set()                         # For multiple parallel pipelines use a barrier?
        $Null = $Sync['WaitJob'].WaitOne(5000)
        $Output = $Sync['Output']                               # $powerShell.Invoke ?
        If ($Null -ne $Output) {
            $Output
        }
        else {
            $PowerShell.Dispose()
            $PowerShell = $Null
        }
    }
    '{0} - {1}' -f $_, $SyncItem
}
```

Unfortunately, the result is quite slow, besides I am lacking detailed knowledge of thread signaling, data collectors and I running into bugs (#7626) to make this stable.
Anyways, for the highlevel design, I think the way to implement this, would be:
- Initiate a thread for each scripblock (supplied by the proposed `-SynchronouslyProcess` parameter)
- in the thread, `Invoke-Command` the scriptblock and pipe it to a `ForEach-Object`
(as in the above example: `Invoke-Command $Sync['Command'] | ForEach-Object `)
- For each item, (synchronized) share it with the main script (using a [`PSDataCollector`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.management.automation.psdatacollection-1)?)
- Block the pipeline in the thread (with a [`Barrier`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.threading.barrier?view=net-5.0)?) ***after*** each item
- Take care of the fact that the parallel thread might run out of objects.

In the main thread:
- Initiate a thread for each scripblock (see above)
- Start the main pipeline (`ForEach-Object`)
- ***Before*** processing each current item (`$_`), implement a barrier (shared with all the above launched threads)
to wait for all the parallel thread to supply their next item.
- Make the parallel items available (e.g. in a `$SyncItem[]`) and process the current

<sub>(I hope it makes some sense)</sub>

> The error is quiet clear but I have you clue how to resolve this (and is I want this, maybe I should do some more playing around in a sandbox).

You can update PowerShell or alternatively just change any instances of that pattern (e.g. `is null` to `== null` and `is not null` to `!= null`)

---

re: the thread based version.  If every deferred pipeline spawns a new thread that could get out of hand pretty quickly if folks don't know how heavy it is.  On top of that you'll end up losing state since you'll also need to spawn a new runspace for each one, which I don't think the user will expect for this functionality.

It's a cool idea, but I'm not sure it solves enough problems to justify the overhead, usage complication or implementation challenge.

@SeeminglyScience:

Good point about not being able to use the caller's state being a limitation that may surprise users, but the same applies at least in principle to `ForEach -Parallel`, where you need `$using:` to reference the caller's state. How would/can something like `$using` work with a thread-based approach?

I'd expect the number of input blocks to be limited, so perhaps the thread count is even less of a concern than with `ForEach-Object -Parallel`.

@iRon7:

> I have had it some deeper thoughts and I agree that this shouldn't require a different syntax.
But I think that the ForEach-Object should have an additional parameter instead,

Yes, that was [my suggestion too](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/15206#issuecomment-818269432) (I only used a different name for the proof-of-concept, because it wasn't a superset of `ForEach-Object`).
I've been struggling to come up with a good switch name, however, given that it would ideally convey _two_ aspects: accepting _script blocks_ as input, and processing their output in a synchronized fashion.

> @SeeminglyScience:
> 
> Good point about not being able to use the caller's state being a limitation that may surprise users, but the same applies at least in principle to `ForEach -Parallel`, where you need `$using:` to reference the caller's state. How would/can something like `$using` work with a thread-based approach?

I imagine it could be used in much the same way.  This would most likely need to be implemented as a custom sort of `Out-Default`, not much different than `-Parallel` otherwise. The hard part is communicating to the user that they need it for this, and ensuring that it's worth the trouble.

We discussed this in the Engine Working Group today and while this is a compelling idea, we think:

- The proposed functionality doesn't mesh well with PowerShell's existing enumeration paradigm
- Other alternatives exist for implementing lazy enumeration in PowerShell today
- There's not a clear justification for needing to first-class a mechanism like this at a language/syntax level
- The proposed pipeline syntax itself would have consequences for parsing pipelines, especially interactively
- The number and extent of changes that would be required to implement this would be difficult to justify compared to the benefit of the feature
- It's not clear that there's a lot of demand or potential utility for this proposal
- Without an example implementation, a proposal of this size requires a clear demand or scenario to motivate it

With that in mind, we are declining the feature request.
